abstract: <jats:title>Abstract</jats:title><jats:p>Both safety and efficacy of medical treatment can vary depending on the ethnogeographic background of the patient. One of the reasons underlying this variability is differences in pharmacogenetic polymorphisms in genes involved in drug disposition, as well as in drug targets. Knowledge and appreciation of these differences is thus essential to optimize population-stratified care. Here, we provide an extensive updated analysis of population pharmacogenomics in ten pharmacokinetic genes (<jats:italic>CYP2D6</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>CYP2C19</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>DPYD</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>TPMT</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>NUDT15</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>SLC22A1</jats:italic>), drug targets (<jats:italic>CFTR</jats:italic>) and genes involved in drug hypersensitivity (<jats:italic>HLA-A</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>HLA-B</jats:italic>) or drug-induced acute hemolytic anemia (<jats:italic>G6PD</jats:italic>). Combined, polymorphisms in the analyzed genes affect the pharmacology, efficacy or safety of 141 different drugs and therapeutic regimens. The data reveal pronounced differences in the genetic landscape, complexity and variant frequencies between ethnogeographic groups. Reduced function alleles of <jats:italic>CYP2D6</jats:italic>, <jats:italic>SLC22A1</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>CFTR</jats:italic> were most prevalent in individuals of European descent, whereas <jats:italic>DPYD</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>TPMT</jats:italic> deficiencies were most common in Sub-Saharan Africa. Oceanian populations showed the highest frequencies of <jats:italic>CYP2C19</jats:italic> loss-of-function alleles while their inferred CYP2D6 activity was among the highest worldwide. Frequencies of <jats:italic>HLA-B*15:02</jats:italic> and <jats:italic>HLA-B*58:01</jats:italic> were highest across Asia, which has important implications for the risk of severe cutaneous adverse reactions upon treatment with carbamazepine and allopurinol. <jats:italic>G6PD</jats:italic> deficiencies were most frequent in Africa, the Middle East and Southeast Asia with pronounced differences in variant composition. These variability data provide an important resource to inform cost-effectiveness modeling and guide population-specific genotyping strategies with the goal of optimizing the implementation of precision public health.</jats:p>
